required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acupoint Stimulation Improve Cognitive Function in Elderly Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Transcutaneous Electrical Acupoint Stimulation on Postoperative Cognitive Function in Elderly Patients

brief_summary.textblock: Postoperative cognitive dysfunction is with increased incidence in elderly patients. Previous studies have shown that acupuncture related techniques could induce protection against brain ischemia and improve outcome after cerebral diseases. In this study the effect of transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation on postoperative cognitive function will be evaluated.

study_design_info.masking_description: transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation is given by an investigator who is not involved in anesthesia and outcome assessment

primary_outcome.measure: Score of mini-mental state examination at 24 hours after surgery
primary_outcome.time_frame: from end of surgery to 24 hours after surgery

primary_outcome.measure: Score of mini-mental state examination at 72 hours after surgery
primary_outcome.time_frame: from end of surgery to 72 hours after surgery

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from end of sevoflurane inhalation to 2 minutes after extubation, at an average of 20 minutes
at the end of the surgery
at the end of the surgery
at the end of the surgery
at the end of the surgery
at the end of the surgery
at the end of the surgery

arm_group.description: electrodes attached and electrical stimulation is given
electrodes attached but no electrical stimulation is given

intervention.description: electrodes are attached to acupoints Zusanli (ST36), Neiguan (PC6) and Hegu (LI4)
electrodes are ligated to a stimulator and electrical stimulation is given

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients scheduled for elective abdominal surgery under general anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age<65 years or >100 years
- American Society of Anesthesiologists status >2
- Existed neurologic or psychiatric disease
- Existed or suspected abuse of drugs or alcohol
- Mini-mental state examination score <24

reference.citation: Hovens IB, van Leeuwen BL, Mariani MA, Kraneveld AD, Schoemaker RG. Postoperative cognitive dysfunction and neuroinflammation; Cardiac surgery and abdominal surgery are not the same. Brain Behav Immun. 2016 May;54:178-193. doi: 10.1016/j.bbi.2016.02.003. Epub 2016 Feb 8.

Feng PP, Deng P, Liu LH, Ai Q, Yin J, Liu Z, Wang GM. Electroacupuncture Alleviates Postoperative Cognitive Dysfunction in Aged Rats by Inhibiting Hippocampal Neuroinflammation Activated via Microglia/TLRs Pathway. Evid Based Complement Alternat Med. 2017;2017:6421260. doi: 10.1155/2017/6421260. Epub 2017 Jun 8.

Liu PR, Zhou Y, Zhang Y, Diao S. Electroacupuncture alleviates surgery-induced cognitive dysfunction by increasing α7-nAChR expression and inhibiting inflammatory pathway in aged rats. Neurosci Lett. 2017 Oct 17;659:1-6. doi: 10.1016/j.neulet.2017.08.043. Epub 2017 Aug 24.

Zhang Q, Li YN, Guo YY, Yin CP, Gao F, Xin X, Huo SP, Wang XL, Wang QJ. Effects of preconditioning of electro-acupuncture on postoperative cognitive dysfunction in elderly: A prospective, randomized, controlled trial. Medicine (Baltimore). 2017 Jun;96(26):e7375. doi: 10.1097/MD.0000000000007375.

patient_data.ipd_description: The data of the study will be available for sharing after publishing, including data of the outcomes
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: The data of the study will be available for sharing after publishing on peer-reviewed journals, and will be available for 5 years
